Founded by Charles Jones and Sir James Crockett in Northampton, England. Daniel Craig's James Bond in Skyfall wore a pair of Crockett & Jones shoes.

Founded as J&J Crombie Ltd by John Crombie and his son James in Aberdeen, Scotland as a manufacturer. The business started making coats under their own label, and eventually retailing at 3 UK locations and 40+ stockists worldwide.
Founded in Edinburgh as a menswear designer boutique, which has expanded to include ladies clothing.
Independent mens boutique opened during the 1970s in Chichester, on the corner of St.Johns Street.

Founded as S.Simpson by Simeon Simpson was a manufacturer of bespoke tailoring based in London. In 1935 Simeon's son Alexander invented the first supporting trouser, and branded it DAKS. In 1936 Alexander opened the first Simpsons store - Simpsons of Picadilly to sell he companies clothing. In 1991 the business was sold to Sankyo Seiko Co. Limited, who at the turn of the century moved the store from Picadilly to Old Bond Street and renamed the business DAKS.
Founded by Walter James Daniel in Oxford and is a royal warrant holder.
Ladies clothing company based in Leamington Spa that specializes in Danish and Scandinavian design.
Founded as a menswear store in Bury St Edmunds in 2015.
Menswear boutique based in Huntriss Row in Scarborough.
Independent menswear store opened in Bury St Edmund in 1906.

Founded in Hanover Street in 1803, it moved to its current location in Savile Row in 1986. Owns several other tailoring companies - Bostridge and Curties and Watson, Fargerstrom and Hughes, Johns and Pegg, James and James, Wells of Mayfair and Fallan & Harvey.

Founded by William Clark in 1778 at Wigmore Street, London. Since 1993 the business has the 'Designers at Debenhams' brand, which sees designer clothing at High Street prices, with designers including Jasper Conran, John Rocha, Betty Jackson Black, Butterfly by Matthew Williamson, H! by Henry Holland, Star by Julien Macdonald, Frost French, Erickson Beamon, Eric Van Peterson, Janet Reger, Pip Hackett, Melissa Odabash, Ted Baker, St George by Duffer, Jeff Banks, and Ben de Lisi.
Founded in Lille, France. Came to UK in 1999.
Founded as J Dege & Sons, William Skinner Jnr joined the firm in 1916. Name changed to Dege & Skinner after the Skinner family took control.
Mens bespoke tailors based in St. Georges Street, London, who house tie is mention in John Le Carre's book The Tailor of Panama.
Founded by Swiss Thomas Meyer in Ibiza, Spain as a fashion brand, the first store opened in Spain in 1986. The business opened its first UK store in 2010.
Italian designer brand that opened its first UK retail store in 1996.
Designer brand launched in 2008 by Diesel, with its first store opening in Conduit Street, London in 2014.
Founded as a fashion house in Paris, the business has 5 stand alone stores and several concessions spread across London.
Italian Designer brand that operates five stores and a concession in London.
Founded by Donald Rooke in a former Hepworth's store that he had started working in during 1969.
Founded in 1909 as H. P. Newman, the store changed its name to Dorothy Perkins in 1919. Purchased from the Farmer family in 1979 by Burtons.
Founded by Michael Drake as a scarf manufacturer. They went on to make Ties, Pocket Squares and Shirts. They opened their flagship store in Clifford Street in 2011.

Founded as a shoe design by Dr. Karl Märtens in Munich, the design was licensed to British shoe manufacturer R. Griggs Group Ltd who anglicised the name, changed the heal and added trademark yellow stitching. In 1994 the business opened its first store in Covent Garden. In 2013 the business was purchased by Permira.
Founded by Dean & Dan Caten with funding from employers Diesel. The UK store opened in March 2015.
Founded by Mitchell Jacobs in Suffolk as a cufflink brand. Opened first boutique in Notting Hill, London in 1998. In 2006 Mitchell Jacobs sold the business.
Founded by Edward Ducker in Oxford, where they are still based. Has appeared in the film Atonement and has many well known customers.

Started as a concession in Oxford Street in 1992, The business operates 50 stand alone stores in the Uk as well as concessions. In 2009 it purchased the brands of Shoe Studio from the administrator of Baugur.
Founded by Ben Dunne in Cork, Ireland as a drapery. Became a full line department store opening its first UK store in the 1970s.
Founded by Dave Whelan in March 2009 after purchasing 50 JJB Sports Fitness clubs and their attached sports stores.

Founded on the Fulham Road, London as a small independent boutique. In June 2015 the business went into administration but was purchased in a pre-packaged deal by East Lifestyle plc, however 19 stores were closed. This left 37 stores and various concessions across the UK.

Danish footwear manufacturer and retailer started in Bredebro by Karl Toosbuy. First ECCO stores in the UK were franchises run by former Clarks executive Michael Fiennes, who grew the number of stores to 17 by 1999, before ECCO took over the running of the brand's stores.

The company was founded in 1689 by William and Martha Shudall. The present name dates from 1902 and is a result of the inheriting of the business by Joseph Ede and then merging with wig-maker Ravenscroft. They have three stores in London, and also in Oxford, Cambridge and Edinburgh. The company holds the Royal warrant as "Purveyors to the British Royal Family" as robemakers to HM The Queen, HRH Prince Philip and HRH Prince Charles
Incorporated in 1997, the business has stores in Cumbria and Derbyshire.
Created by the Langholm Dyeing and Finishing Company. First store opened Randolph Place, Edinburgh.
Founded by Alvaro and Clemente Cebrian in 2004. The first UK store was opened in Carnaby Street, London in 2012.
French designer clothing brand that opened its first UK store in London in 2013.
Founded by Robert Emmett in Kings Road, London in 1992.
Founded by Thomas Mahon, who had previously started Steed Bespoke Tailors. Known to provide suits for the Prince of Wales.
Italian Designer brand starated by Gimmo Etra. The business opened its first stand alone UK store in August 2011.
Founded in 1930 by manufacturer Jack Green. Purchased by Burtons in 1970.
Welsh bespoke tailor and designer who started out on his own in 1989, opening his first store in London in 1993.

Started as a high end fashion label within French Connection. In 2010 sold by French Connection to Opengate Connection, but in 2013 the business went into administration. The business was saved by Maxine Hargreaves-Adams, the daughter of Matalan founder John Hargreaves.
Founded at Museum Street, London WC1A as a menswear store.
Founded by Tim Slade and Jules Leaver as a business selling T-shirts at ski resorts, the business opened its first retail store in 1993. In 2007 the business was acquired by Bridgepoint Capital.
Founded in Rome by Edoardo and Adele Fendi as a fur and leather shop. Since 2001 the business has been part of LVMH.
Founded in Newcastle by John James Fenwick. Now operates 11 stores including subsidiaries Bentalls and William & Griffin.
Founded in 1973, the outdoor clothing and camping specialists had expanded to 11 stores when Sports Direct purchased 60% of the business in 2007.
Keswick based retailer located in the famous Abrahams Photography store and equipping early expeditions to Everest. Purchased by Tiso in 2007.
Founded by Anne Fontaine, with her first boutique opening in Paris in 1994. Famous for White Shirts.
Founded by the founders of JD Sport, John Wardle and David Makin after they sold the business in 2005.
Founded by Woolworth company, Kinney Shoe Corporation in 1974.
Founded by Tom Ford, the former creative director of Gucci and YSL. The first standalone UK store opened in Sloane Street, London in 2012.
American chain opened in 1984 as Fashion 21. First UK store opened 2010.
Founded in the 1960s, the men's tailors operates from Petersfield in Hampshire.
Founded by Stephen Marks as a ladies mid market brand, the business expanded into menswear in 1976. Now operates over 130 stores across UK & Europe.
Independent country clothing stores based in Norwich

Founded as a shirt manufacturer in America, the retail business was started by the former Swedish franchise owner Pyramid Sportswear. The business is now owned by Swiss department store group Maus Frères.
Founded by Donald and Doris Fisher in San Francisco in 1969. First UK store opened in 1987
Founded in Bristol as an independent fashion boutique.
Handmade men's footwear manufacturer who opened their first UK store in Savile Row in 2013.
Founded by Kurt Geiger, an Austrian who opened his first store in Bond Street, London.
Founded in Italy by Mario Polegato. The second largest shoe manufacturer in the world after Clarks.

Founded by Tanya Sarne and Katharine Hamnett in London. Started out as a fashion label, it was purchased by Kevin Stanford and investment company Arev and went on to have 32 shops across the UK. The business went into administration in 2008 and was saved by Touker Suleyman. It now operates 3 stores and several concessions in department stores.
Founded as two separate companies - Gieves (1887) and Hawkes (1771). Merged after Gieves & Co purchased Hawkes & Co. Based at No. 1 Savile Row.
Independent Ladies boutique opened in Timber Hill, Norwich by Jonathan Trumbull & Hatters, a separate boutique in Norwich which has been opened since 1971.
Founded by Jane Lewis as a designer knitwear brand, the business opened its first store at Conduit Street, London.

Founded as Camping and Caravanning Centre in Sheffield, the business was purchased by a management buyout in 1998, and in 2004 the business opened its first Go Outdoors store, eventually re-branding the business.
Independent Outdoor clothing and camping equipment store based in Chester.
Founded as an outwear store over 30 years ago in Shiremoor.
Rebranded name for the Clysdale Rubber Company, the business purchased their Glasgow rival, Lumleys in 1959 before rebranding that as Greaves in the 1980s.
Founded by William Greenwood as a hatters shop. At its peak in the 1990s the business had over 200 shops, but after entering administration in 2009 it now has 80 stores.

Handmade shoe manufacturer that started by William Green in Rushden, UK. Business was renamed Grenson, as a shortening of William Green & Son in 1913. The business opened its first retail store in Liverpool Street, London in 2008.
Founded in 1999 by Karl Dunkley and John Quigley as a British shirt making firm. Store is located in Jermyn Street, London.
Founded in Florence, Italy by Guccio Gucci. The business operates eight stand alone stores in the UK and several concessions in department stores.
Founded by Paul and Maurice Marciano in Beverley Hills, Los Angeles USA. Guess re-entered the UK market in 2004 with a store in Covent Garden.
Founded in Sweden by Erling Persson, with the first UK store opening in 1976 - its first outside of Scandinavia. Originally traded as Hennes in UK.

Founded by Jeremy Hackett and Ashley Lloyd-Jennings from a stall on London's Portobello Road, with the first shop opening in Kings Road, Chelsea. Operates 13 stores in UK plus concessions, which is a total of 77 stores across 16 countries.
Founded in 1908 in Chichester, West Sussex by Joscelyn Hansford, and run by Matthew Hansford his grandson since 1990.
Upmarket department store in Knightsbridge, London which was founded by Charles Henry Harrod.

Founded by Benjamin Harvey as a linen shop within a house on the corner of Sloane Street and Knightsbridge. In 1991 Dickson Concepts purchased the business from the Burton Group, and expanded the business to 14 stores across the world.
Founded in 1949 by Thomas Harvie and George Hudson, it remains the only family owned shirtmaker in Jermyn Street, London.
The company was founded by two outfitters, Ralph Hawes and Freddie Curtis, who opened the first store in Piccadily Arcade at the corner with Jermyn Street, in London in 1913.

Outdoor wear store opened in Hawkshead Village. Bought by Burtons in 1996. Sold to Rubicon retail in 2002, who sold the business off in 2003 to Retail Variations. Retail Variations went into administration in 2003 and the business was sold to Daffodil Holdings in 2003. Went into Administration in 2006, before being purchased by Vertical Acquisitions. This however was short lived and the business returned to administration later that August and was purchased by Branded Logo. Business went into administration again in 2007, and was resucued by the outdoor clothing company Regatta.
Started as a harness manufacturer by Thierry Hermès. Operates stand alone stores and concessions within department stores.
Founded as a bespoke tailors by Savile Row aprentices Anthony Hewitt, the business also incorporates the former independent tailors Airey & Wheeler of Picadilly, who went into administration in 1996.

Founded as Northern Outsize Menswear by Bernard Levy as a mail order firm. The business opened its first store on Edgware Road, London in 1959. During the 1970s the business changed its name to High and Mighty. In 2009 the business was purchased out of administration by J D Williams.
American designer brand that opened its flagship store in Brompton Road, London in August 2011.
Stephen Hitchcock established his own tailoring business after serving his apprenticeship at Anderson & Sheppard.
Founded as a shoe brand, the business has expanded to sell a full range of clothing.
Independent sports retailer based in Cambridge owned by Jarrolds department store.

Hobson & Bates was founded during the 1980s and grew to include 3 stores operating under the Bawtry Shoe, Hobson and Bates names. In 2014 the business entered a CVA, and a new company purchased the Hobson and Bawtry shops.
Founded by Abercromie & Fitch as a brand aimed at 14-18 year olds, the business opened its first store in the UK at Brent Cross in October 2008.
Department store chain founded in Torquay. Expanded to take in 3 former department stores across the UK.
Small chain of shoe shops for children.
Based in Alnwick, the store was unsuccessfully asked to stop using the name by Tottenham Hotspur.

Started as a concept by Stewart Houlgrave in his parents business Beaconsfield Footwear. The started selling by mail order catalogue direct to customers in 1996, opening their first retail store in Southport in the year 2000.

Department store chain founded in Glasgow by Hugh Fraser. In 1948 it was listed on the London Stock Exchange. In 1985 the business was purchased by the Al-Fayed family, but returned as a public company in 1994. In 2006 it was purchased by the Highland consortium, before being purchased by Sanpower.
Founded as a print based brand of homewares, the founders Javvy Royle and Frieda Gormley moved into clothing. The British made goods brand opened its flagship store in Shoreditch High Street in 2013.

Founded as a small shop on Liverpool's London Road, in 1925 the business was offered the former Owen Owen store for part ownership of the business. In 1992 the business was floated, before being purchaed by JJB Sports in 2000. In 2002 the business was purchased by PPM Capital, who had sold the business to Silverfleet Capital in 2003. The business expanded to 57 stores however in 2011 the business was sold to Endless, a turnaround specialist but they put the business into administration in June 2011. 6 of the stores and the trading name were purchased from the administrators by Lewis's Home Retail.
Founded by William Hunt, a former professional footballer on the Kings Road, the Savile Row store opened in 1998.

Founded as the North British Rubber Company by American Henry Lee Norris, the manufacturer of Green Welly boots branched initially into retail in 2006 with a store in Carnaby Street. However, in 2015 a new store was opened in Regent Street, London.
Founded by Mr. Henry Huntsman, from previous business H Huntsman, a breeches maker. One of the founders of the Savile Row Bespoke Association
Founded by Donna Ida in Chelsea, London, the business sells ladies jeans in its London stores.
Founded in Australia, the designer brand opened its first UK store in 2013.
Italian brand founded in Dossobuono di Villafranca di Verona.
Online brand of N Brown Group, which opened its first physical stores in 2011. Dual branded stores with Simply Be
Jeanswear firm started by Bestseller in 1990.

Founded by Lewis Tomalin as Dr Jaeger's Sanitary Woollen System Co Ltd' in 1884, capitalising on a craze for wool-jersey long johns inspired by the theories of German scientist Dr Gustav Jaeger. The company's flagship store opened on Regent Street in the 1930s.
Saville Row tailor shop founded by former British Fashion Council's Menswear and Bespoke Designer of the Year.
Discount footwear store founded by importer Florentine Shoes that is based in the South East.

Founded as Popular Merchandise, Inc, during the 1980s the business expanded into the catalogue market with Popular Club Plan. In 1989 the business became J.Crew and opened its first retail store. Its first UK store opened in Regents Street in 2011.
Started in Bury by John and David Makin. Became a plc in 1996. In 2005 Pentland Group bought out the Makins.
The company was started in 1972 by John Robinson and Malcolm Webster.
Founded by Laura Tenison as a mail order business.
Small footwear chain based in the south east.
Independent boutique that opened in 1971 based in St. Stephens Street, Norwich. Owns the Ginger boutique in Norwich.
Founded by Alfred Jones in Bayswater, London.

Founded by Joseph Ettedgui and his family in Kings Road, Chelsea below their hairdressing salon. First large scale retail store opened in Sloane Street in 1979, designed by Norman Foster. It has been owned by Onward Kashiyama since 2005.
Small chain of childrenswear stores in Hampshire and Dorset. Named after the owners children Josh, Tom and Hannah.

Founded by Ian Joule as Joule & Sons, the business originally sold branded clothing and accessories at equestrian and country shows. In 1994 the business rebranded as Joules, and in 1999 launched its own clothing collection. In 2000 the brand opened its first store, in Market Harborough and has since pened 92 branches and several concessions across the UK.
Ladies fashion store, which was in the news in 2014 for an offensive response to a message on Twitter.
Founded in California, initially as Travis Jeans. the first UK store was opened in 2009 in Bruton Street, London.
Founded by Donna Karan in New York, the business opened its only UK store in Conduit Street, London in 1997.
Founded in February 1975 in Westbury, Wiltshire and specializes in small, tall and the big sizes.
Founded in 1882 as T & F French in Piccadilly, in 1923 French merged with existing Savile Row tailor A.H. Kilgour to form Kilgour & French. Owned by Fung Group since 2013.
American designer brand started by Michael Kor in 1981. First UK store opened in Regent Street, London in 2015.
Founded by former French Tennis player Rene Lacoste. The UK flagship store in Brompton Road, London opened in 2012.
Founded by German fashion designer of the same name, Karl has also been the head designer of Chanel and Fendi. His boutique on Regent Street, Lodnon opened in November 2013.
Founded as a dressmaker in France by Jeanne Lanvin. The Menswear store opened in London in 2008.
Founded by Ralph Lauren as a Mens Tie brand, the first UK store opened in New Bond Street, London in 1981.
Founded by Émile Camuset in France, the business opened its first stand alone store in the UK in 2013.
Founded in Rhondda, Wales by James Henry Leeke as a builder's merchants. In the 1970s the business expanded into department stores offering Outdoor clothing and footwear.
Founded by Thomas Mayes Lewin in Jermyn Street. In the 1980s the business started to expand by opening its second store at Lime Street, London.
Started by John Lewis in Oxford Street, London. In 1920 was incorporated into John Lewis Partnership. Largest department store in volume of revenue.

Founded by the Lillywhite family in Haymarket, London. Moved to their current location at 25 Regent Street, London in 1925. Opened stores in numerous city locations. At one time owned by the Forte Group, it was purchased by Jerónimo Martins in 1996. The business struggled in the competitive UK sports market and in 2002 was sold to Sports Direct. Stores were changed to Sports Direct or closed between 2002 and 2012, leaving the Regent Street store as the sole location.
Created by Phillip Lim, an American designer in 2005. The London store opened in 2013.
Ladies shoe store based in around the M25 in Essex.

The company, founded in London, began trading as a wholesale fashion brand in 1988, going on to open concessions in department stores. In 2006 the management team purchased the business, before selling it on in 2008 to Next plc, the same year as their first store opened in Brent Cross Shopping Centre.
Founded by the Marchi brothers in Carpi, Italy.
Founded by Angus Lloyd and Henri Strzelecki in Manchester. Operates its own stores and concessions in House of Fraser.
The first store was opened in 1976 on Chiltern Street in the West End of London. The business is a clothing and shoe brand for tall women 5'8" and over.
Started in the 19th century by the Loro Piana family as wool fabric merchants. In 2013 80% of the business was purchased by LVMH.
Founded in Paris, the business operates 3 stand alone stores in London and concessions within Selfridges and Harvey Nicholls.
Founded in Vancouver, Canada in 1998 by Chip Wilson. Opened its first UK store in Covent Garden in February 2014.
Founded as a knitwear firm in the Scottish town of Hawick, the business opened its first retail store in London, in 2005.
Founded by McGeoch family as pawnbrokers in Paisley, Renfrewshire. Converted to clothing in 1953. In 1973 adopted Mackays name. M&Co brand launched in 2003, with all stores being rebranded by 2007.
Launched in 2006 as a lower price range to Alexander McQueen, the business opened its first store in Spitalfields in 2012.
Founded as a fashion house by Alexander McQueen, the business was bought by Gucci in 2000 and opened retail stores across the globe.
Founded by brothers Isak Andic and Nahman Andic in Barcelona.
Founded by Mark Marengo, the brand opened its first store at 31 Savile Row, London
Founded by Eugenio Marinella in 1914 in Naples.

The company was founded by a partnership between Michael Marks, a Belarusian Jew & Thomas Spencer, a cashier from Skipton in North Yorkshire, as a Penny Bazaar in Leeds Kirgate Market. Now one of the UK's largest clothing retailers.
International designer shoe brand that opened its first UK store in Westfield White City, London in 2013.

Founded as a men's clothing manufacturer in 1985, the business was purchased by Inditex Group in 1991, who expanded the range to women's clothing in 1992. The first UK Store was opened on Regent Street, London in 2003.
Founded by John Hargreaves in Preston.
Founded in London, it is now an international retailer with retail stores and an online site.
Founded by Achille Maramotti in Italy. Operates four stand alone stores and concessions in department stores.
Founded in 2011 by Lorenzo Fluxa, a member of the family that created Camper shoes. The first UK store was opened in London in 2013.
Founded in 1971 in Brazil, the first UK store opened in Covent Garden, London in 2014.
Founded by Joseph Alexander in Cookstown as a drapery. In 1970s bought Menary Brothers and changed the group name to this. Now operates as a department store.

Started by fashion designer Rattan Chadha and his business partners PK Sen Sharma, Adu Advaney, Suveer Arora, Ronny Lemmens, Horatio Ho and Arun Mehta in the 1970s as a supplier of clothes for department and wholesale stores in the Netherlands. In 1980 they created two popular clothing brands—"Moustache" for men and "Emanuelle" for women, and in 1986 brought these together a M (from Moustache) + E (from Emanuelle) + XX (an abbreviation for "kiss kiss") to create MEXX. In the UK the business has 17 stores mainly in Northern Ireland.

Founded by Karen Millen and Kevin Stanford. First store opened in 1983. Bought by Mosaic Fashions, owners of Oasis in 2004. Mosaic went into administration in 2009. Bought out by the management team under Aurora Fashions. Karen Millen was split off as an independent company in 2011.

Founded as the young fashion section of Selfridges department store by Charles Clore. Later opened in Lewis department stores and as separate stores. In 1999 Miss Selfridge was purchased by Arcadia Group as part of Sir Philip Green's purchase of Sears plc.
Started by Peter Simon in Portabello Road market in 1972, opening his first Monsoon store in 1973.
Founded in Milan by Franco Moschino.
Founded by Moses Moss in Covent Garden. Has owned several brands including the UK retail arm of Hugo Boss

Founded by Selim Zilkha & Sir James Goldsmith are purchasing 50 store W.J. Harris nursery furniture chain. Became a public company in 1972. Merged with Habitat in 1982, and then BHS in 1986 to form Storehouse plc. Purchased Children's World from Boots in 1996 and rebranded Mothercare World. In 1999 Storehouse changed its name to Mothercare plc after the sale of BHS to Sir Philip Green.

Started life as retail arm of Karrimor. Name changed to Mountain Warehouse after sale of Karrimor in 1999. Business changed hands in 2002; 2007; 2010 and finally in 2013 to its former founder Mark Neale.
Founded in 1995, the business operates two stores in the Wood Green Shopping City, London.
Ladies boutique specializing in Italian design based in Suffolk.
Founded in Fort William by Ian A Sykes MBE and Ian D Sutherland. Acquired by Jacobs & Turner in 2007.

Founded by Miss Elisabeth New and Mr Samuel Lingwood in Eton, becoming the official outfitters to the college. In 1922 they opened a store in Jermayn Street which was destroyed during the Blitz. They now operate from the Piccadilly Arcade, London.
Started in Taunton by Tony Singh. Purchased by Brait SA in May 2015.
Started in 1982 after the purchase of Kendall & Sons Ltd by clothing manufacturer Joseph Hepworth. Next took over as the operational name of Joseph Hepworth & Son and Kendalls.
Founded by Paul Goodyer as a market stall in Reading.

Founded by Norman Freed in 1955, the business was sold to Graphite Capital in 2002 for £70m. In 2005 it was purchased by Bagur before going into administration in 2011. Edinburgh Woollen Mills bought the brand and 33 of its 116 stores, but in 2014 the business again was put into administration and bought out in a pre-packaged deal by Edinburgh Woollen Mills. All stores were closed and the business now operates concessions in department sores and online.
Norton & Sons is a Savile Row bespoke tailor founded in 1821 by Walter Grant Norton. The firm is located on the East side of the street, at No. 16.
Founded as a subsidiary of Svenska Jeans AB by Maria Erixon in 2001, opening its first store in Soho, London in 2014.

Floated in 1995, in 2001 business was purchased by a management buyout. A second buyout occurred in 2004. This buyout called Mosiac Fashions went into administration in 2009. Bought out by another management team under Aurora Fashions.
Formed as a concession in Hyper Hyper, before opening its first store in 1984.
Fashion sports stores created by Office.
Founded in 1804 by the Oldrid family, the business operates two Oldrid department stores and several Downtown stores.
Swimwear designer brand started in March 2007.
Founded in America by Charles F. Orvis, the family-owned retail and mail-order business specialises in high-end fly fishing, hunting and sporting goods.
Opened by Sears plc in Reading, the store sold the brands of Sears plc in out of town locations. Purchased by Sir Philip Green in 1999, and became part of Arcadia Group.
Founded by George Pakeman in Old Swindon in 1876. Now operates in Cirencester, with a department within McEwans of Perth.
Founded by Garwood Burton Palmer as a drapery store in Great Yarmouth.
Founded by Gianfranco Barizza and Aronne Miola and named after an ancient building in the historic centre of Vicenza.
Family owned business started in York by Catherine Paver, initially as shoe parties. First store opened in Scarborough.
Started as Peacocks Penny Bazaar in Warrington. Went public in 1999, before a management buyout in 2005. Went into administration in 2012 before being purchased by Edinburgh Woollen Mill.
Founded by Nat Peal as a men's haberdashery in London's Burlington Arcade. In 2010 the business was purchased by Adam Holdsworth and Nick Falkingham in 2007.
Founded by Andy Bond, a former Asda executive and South African retail business Pepkor. The business opened 50 stores in 50 days.
Founded by Patsy Seddon at Wandsworth Common, London.
Independent sports retailer based in Norwich owned by Jarrolds department store.
Founded in Paris in 1855, the UK store is based in New Bond Street, London.

Founded by brothers James, Peter and John Mullen as a specialist shirt company based in London. In 2011 the business opened its first stores in Washington DC, Edinburgh, and a concession within Harrods in London.
Founded in the early 1980s by Pietro Negra and Cristina Rubini, the business operates 1 stand alone store and concessions within Harvey Nicholls and Harrods.
Opened in Brunswick Square, London before moving to Savile Row in 1846. Moved to Cork Street in 1961 before returning to Savile Row in 1982.
Upmarket boutique footwear retailer started by Office.
Upmarket boutique footwear retailer started by Office.
Founded by Mario Prada in Milan, Italy. The business operates three stand alone stores and concessions in several department stores.
Opened by Arthur Ryan in Dublin as Penneys. Opened first UK store in Belfast in 1971.
Founded as New Wear S.a. in Naron, Galicia, Spain in 1986. The business became part of Inditex Group who rebranded the business as Pull & bear in 1991, and opened its first UK store in 2008.
Founded in Norwich under the name Quality Discounts. Multi range discounter. Some stores have in store Brantano concessions.
Formed with the merger of the Braintree and Chelmsford Co-operative societies.
Started as manufacturer of reclaimed canvas sailcloth jackets in Salcombe, Devon. Now operates a manufacturer and retailer of sea inspired clothing and homewares.
Opened in 1993 with 3 stores in Scotland. Went into administration in 2009 but bought back in a pre-packaged deal.

Started in London in 1990. Purchased by Burtons in 1996. Sold as part of Rubicon deal in 2002, who sold the business to Speciality Retail Group in the same year. Speciality Retail Group (SRG) were purchased by Former Moss Bros chief executive Adrian Wright & private equity group Gresham. SRG went into administration in 2010, bought by Arafa Holdings and merged with Baird Menswear Brands to form Bairds.

Founded as running shoe company J W Foster & Sons, the business opened its first stand alone store in 2004 in Covent Garden, London. The business was bought by Adidas in 2005. In 2011 Reebok opened its new retail concept Reebok Fithub.
Founded in Red Wing, Minnesota by Charles H. Beckman, the business operates a stand-alone store in London selling their own brand shoes.
Founded by the Reiss family in 1971, the business operates 56 stores and several concessions across the UK.
Fashion clothing brand that opened its first stores in 2007.

Ladies underwear retailer founded in 1939 by Hungarian immigrant Gita Peller and Bertha Rigby, an English corsetière at South Molton Street in London's West End. In 2011 87% of the business was purchased by Belgium manufacturer Van de Velde.
Founded by the Italian Max Mara company as a plus size designer brand, the business operates one stand alone UK store and concessions within several department stores.

Founded by Bernard Lewis under the name Lewis Separates, the business changed name to Chelsea Girl in 1965. In 1988 it merged with its menswear operation Concept Man to form River Island, with all stores being re-branded by 1991.

Founded by Paul Howcroft and his wife Sarah, the business was purchased by Clarks in 1988. In 1996 it was sold to a management buyout, before changing hands again in 2001. In 2007 the business was purchased by The Cann Trust and Colin Fisher.
Founded in Monaco by Olga Roh. The only UK stoe is based in London.
Founded as a market stall in Camden Market, London. Now operates in Brick Lane, Covent Garden and Camden.
Founded in Ebbw Vale in 1995, the business opened its 50th store in 2011, and 100th in 2014.
Founded in 1979, the southern based business specializes in Country clothing and sponsors Pony Club Polo.
Founded by James Buckley Thorp as an upmarket brand aimed at University students. In 2014 they opened their flagship store at 5 Burton Street, Bath.
Founded in 1873 by the marriage of George Bromley to his employers daughter Elizabeth Russell, with the first store carrying the name in Eastbourne. Opened its first Bond Street store in 1947.
Founded by Sonia Rykiel in Paris, the business was 80% purchased by Fung Brands in 2012.
Sainsburys started selling clothes in its jointly run Savacentres (with BHS). In 2004 it launched its TU clothing range

Men's tailors founded next door to the Savoy Hotel, which was purchased by Cecil Gee, before becoming part of Moss Brothers in 1988. In 2000 many of the Guild stores were converted to the new Code brand created by Moss Brothers, however by 2002 the Code name was dropped, and Savor Taylor Guild became the business' upmarket brand.
Founded as a cloth merchant, the textile manufacturer produces and retails suits, jackets and shirts.

Founded in Edinburgh by Sandy Alexander, it remained as an independent business until it was purchased by a plc. In 1990 a management buyout occurred before being purchased by Genesco, a US footwear retailer in 2011.
Dorothee Schumacher founded her own label in 1989 with her husband, Jörg Singhoff. The business now operates 45 stores across the world.
Dutch designer brand that opened its first UK store in London in 2012.
Founded in Cirencester in 1911, the business claims to be the oldest independent retail business in the town.
Menswear store purchased by Pentland Group, JD Sport's owner in 2005.
Founded out of the Cornish company General Clothing Stores in 2001, as a seaside inspired designer brand.

Founded by Maurice Sedwell in Fleet Street, the business moved to 9 Savile Row in 1963. In 1988 Maurice Sedwell retired selling the business to his employee Andrew Ramroop. The business moved to 19 Savile Row in 1994.
Started out as a value ladies clothing retailer in early 1980s. Moved to a fashion brand retailer in 2004.

Nutters of Savile Row was opened on Valentine's Day 1969 by Tommy Nutter and Edward Sexton, who had worked together at Donaldson, Williamson & Ward. Nutter left business in 1976, but Edward Sexton continues to run the business changing the name in 1982.

Founded by Arthur Benjamin Sugarman in Brighton, the business opened its first store in the city in 1967. The business was purchased by Oxford Industries in 2004 from 3i and Enterprise Equities and discontinued the ladies and children's wear ranges in 2010.

Originally called Bensonshoe, the business was name was first changed to Discount Shoe Zone in 1996 before becoming Shoe Zone in 2001. In 2007 they purchased Shoefayre chain from Co-Op, and added the Stead & Simpson business after purchasing it from administrators in 2008.
Footwear retailer set up by former Clarks executive and ECCO franchise holder, Michael Fiennes with his wife Rosalie. Now operates from 10 stores, 4 concessions and a website
Founded by Donna Reid in Ayr, the business has expanded to 3 stores across Scotland.

Started in 1981 by John Simons, the man who founded the Ivy Shop in Richmond. The store in Covent Garden, London continued to supply the Ivy League look started by the Ivy Shop, however the store closed in 2010. A new store opened in 2011 at 46 Chiltern Street in Marylebone.
Online brand of N Brown Group, which opened its first physical stores in 2011. Dual branded stores with Jacamo.
Founded in Glasgow, Scotland by Samuel Slater, the business is still owned by the Slater family.

Founded as Lea Mills in 1784 by John Smedley and Peter Nightingale, it was in 1825 when John Smedley's son John took over the running of the business and started making clothing not just cloth. Operates a store in Brook Street, London and concessions in several department stores.
Founded by Paul Smith in Nottingham as Paul Smith Vêtements pour Hommes, a mens tailor. He opened his first store in Covent Garden in 1979. The business now operates 17 stores in England.

Founded as a specialist sock retailer by Sophie Mirman and Richard P. Ross. The business expanded to stores across the UK, USA and Europe. However the business entered administration in 1990, and although was purchased by a consortium it struggled and after another peiod of administration it became part of the Facia group. This group failed in 1996, and between then and 2006 had a further 3 owners. The business had closed all of its stores but has since opened a store in the Arndale Centre in Manchester and has concessions in various Mill outlets and department stores.
Founded as Top Footwear for Men in St. Albans, the business changed its name to SOLETRADER in 1992. In the business opened Sole as a store selling luxury brands, in addition to the SOLETRADER stores.
Founded as Top Footwear for Men in St. Albans, the business changed its name to SOLETRADER in 1992. SOLED OUT is a factory outlet store based in the north east.
Founded as Top Footwear for Men in St. Albans, the business changed its name to SOLETRADER in 1992.

Founded by Nick Hart, the retail business formally operated from Savile Row and Brook Street, London before the retail company went into liquidation in 2014. The tailoring side of the business took on the lease of the Brook Street store.

Founded as Mike Ashley Sports in Maindehead, the business changed its name to Preston Sports in 1984. In 1995-96 the business changed its name to Sports Soccer. In 2002 the business purchased rival Lillywhites, and in 2005 the business was again re-branded as Sports World, with a further change occurring in 2007 to Sports Direct. In 2012 it purchased the JJB brand name and 20 of it stores.
Founded by Edward DeBoise and Thomas Mahon. Thomas Mahon left the business in 2002 and in 2008 Edward was joined by his son Matthew.
Created by Grabal Alok, the Indian-owned textile manufacturer that had bought the remnants of QS Stores and Bewise chains that had gone into administration.
Founded by Ray & Chris Stowers, Ray had previously worked for Gieves & Hawkes for 25 years.
Founded as a family owned business in Barcelona, the business became part of the Inditex group in 1999. The first store in the UK opened in Westgate, Stratford in 2014.
Menswear retailer created by Baird group, after parent company Afara bought 12 of the former Suits You stores from the administrator.
Sunspel was founded in 1860 as a manufacturer of clothing by Thomas Hill, and claims to be the first fashion retailer to produce the T-shirt style clothing top.

Founded as Cult Clothing by Ian Hibbs and Julian Dunkerton in Cheltenham. During the 1990s the business expanded into a number of UK university towns and cities, before opening their first Superdry store in Covent Garden in 2004.
Founded by Tamara and Simon Hill-Norton with one boutique in London's Notting Hill selling ladies activewear, by 2003 the business had expanded to 5 stores.
Independent outdoor clothing and equipment store founded in 1977.
Young ladies fashion store located in Northern Ireland and owned by Menarys department store chain
Nick Tentis had been selling vintage suits, until he opened his first store in 1995 selling his own clothing. He opened his store on Savile Row in 2010.
Founded as a luxury clothing menswear retailer in the North West of England, 50% of the business was purchased by JD Sports in 2012 who added five of their Cecil Gee branches to the chain.
Italian lingerie brand which opened its first UK store in 2007.
Founded by Warren Gold, of Lord John (Carnaby Street) fame, from its predecessor Goldrange. Based in Golders Green, London
Started by the Elisha brothers in Paris, the first UK store opened in 2010. Also operates concessions within Harrods and Selfridges.
Made to measure footwear company based in London, Los Angeles and Helsinki.
Claim to be Nottinghamshire's only dedicated children's shoe shop.
Discounter starting life by selling soap overmade by one of founder Peter Blacks factories.
Dutch fashion retailer that opened its first UK store in the former Tower Records store in Regent Street, London in 2009.
Founded by Keith Leaver in the Tetbury, Gloucestershire.
Founded as a brand of The Abington Shoe Company in the USA, the business opened its first UK retail store in 1990 on New Bond Street.
Independent menswear store located in Cirencester.
Founded in 1755 after a merger of older business. Operates in Middle Temple Lane, London.

Founded by Graham Tiso, a mountain climber, in Edinburgh with his wife Maude. in 2006 they purchased the Alpine Bikes business, followed by the George Fisher outdoor store in Keswick in 2007. In 2014 the Tiso family sold a controlling stake in the business to JD Sports.

Founded in the Swedish town of Uddevalla by Markus Schwarmann and Hjalmar Nordstrom, the business has been owned by IC Group since 2003. The business opened its first UK store in 2013 in London. It also operates concessions within Selfridges department stores.
Opened as TJ Maxx in Framingham, Massachusetts in 1976. Opened first UK store in Bristol in 1994 under TK Maxx name to not confuse itself with discount department store TJ Hughes.
Started by Jessica and Jamie Seaton in Wales in 1997 as a mail order pyjama company. French Connection purchased 75% of the company in 2000.
Founded in 1964 as the young ladies fashion department in the Peter Robinson department store. Split off from Peter Robinson as a separate business (by owners Burton Group) in 1973.
Founded by Harry Demopoulos as Silver Shoes, becoming Tower Boots before changing its name to TOWER London.
Department store founded in Braintree that now operates in Essex and Cambridgeshire.
Founded by Stephen Kavanagh in Weymouth.
Founded by Jacobs & Turner, a workwear company operating since 1938, as a brand to move into specialist skiwear and outdoor clothing. The retail business was started in the 1990s.
Founded by John Deane-Bowers in 1991, the business is located in Bury St. Edmunds.

Founded in 1885 by Reginald Turnbull and Ernest Asser, a salesman, in St. James in West London. In 1903 they moved to their Jermyn Street location. The business was purchased by Ali Fayed younger brother of Mohamed Al-Fayed, former owner of Harrods, in 1986.
Founded as a mail order business by Nicholas Charles Tyrwhitt Wheeler, the business opened its first store in Jermyn Street, London in 1997.
Founded by Brian Smith in California, the business was purchased by Deckers Outdoor Corporation in 1995.
Spanish footwear retailer who opened its first UK store on Oxford Street, London in 2014.
Designer brand started by Luciano Benneton in Treviso, which opened stores around the world. Currently only stores in Northern Ireland are operated by Benneton.
UNIQLO is a clothing apparel company, which was originally founded in Yamaguchi, Japan in 1949 as a textiles manufacturer. The company opened its first store in the UK in 2001.
Founded in 1970 by Richard Hayne, Scott Belair, and Gabriel Tham-Morrobel, the American fashion chain opened its first UK stoe in 1998.

Opened as a sports retailer in Edinburgh. Bought by Sir Tom Hunter in 2004. Purchased fully by Sports Direct in 2012. Defunct retailer Republic merged into USC in 2013. Went into Administration in 2015. Business bought by a Sports Direct holding company Republic Retail Ltd in 2015
London Fashion house founded as Robinson Valentine, named after its founders Antonia Robinson and Anna Valentine. When Antonia Robertson left the business the brnad became Anna Valentine.
Founded by the former head of design at Calvin Klein & Ralph Lauren, the US designer brand opened its first UK store in 2014 in Conduit Street.
Founded in Denmark in 1987, the business owned by Bestseller opened its first UK standalone store in Westfield Stratford in 2011.
Founded in America by Roy Raymond, the first UK store opened in Bond Street in 2012, with its ninth store opening in Reading in April 2015.
Founded by Fred Prysquel as a swimwear company in France, and was named after the French for crankshaft.
Originally a brand name for a wool and cotton mix, a Viyella fashion retail business was started by its parent company. Owned by Austin Reed since 2009.
Founded by Amanda Wakeley in Chelsea as a boutique and brand, the business has since expanded its stand alone stores and operates concessions within Harvey Nicholls stores.
Founded by Hernán and Judith de Balcázar as a boutique in Notting Hill, London, the business expanded into mail order in 1999 and online sales in 2000.
Founded by Raphael Nat Wallis in 1923. The business was purchased by Sears Group in 1980. Became part of Arcadia Group in 1999 following the Sears plc purchase by Sir Philip Green.
Business started in London during the 19th Century, and currently operates in Newcastle.

Co founded by Jeff Banks, the business was purchased bt Sears plc. Sears was acquired by Philip Green and Warehouse was transferred to Arcadia Group. In 2002 a management buyout called Rubicon Retail purchased the business. In 2006 Mosaic Fashions took over Rubicon, but went into administration in 2009. A new management buyout called Aurora Fashions bought the business.
Founded by Doug Tilling as a clthing manufacturer of artist T-shirts. In 1999 the business opened its first stores in Cardiff and Bath.
Founded in 1917 on the high street of Eton and became an established military tailor.
Founded by Vivienne Westwood after the break up of her partnership with Malcolm McClaren, the UK business was franchised to Hervia until 2013.
French Designer brand started by Louis Vuttion as a maker of Travel trunks. Its first store opened in London in 1885.

Founded by Katie Thomas by selling stockings, the brand first started as an online retailer before opening its first boutique in London's Portobello in 2003. The business now also operates a boutique in Los Angeles.
Founded by Lucille Lewin. Bought by Mosaic Fashions in 2004. Sold to a business led by Jane Shepherdson in 2008.
Founded by Indian brothers Mahesh and Suresh Ramakrishnan and named after the intersection of two nearby streets.

Founded by George Treves and Sean Thomas as a clothing manufacturer aimed at skiers. The business changed focus away from the skying market and moved into selling their own goods. By 2014 they operated 85 stores and several concessions within the UK.

Founded by Peter Williams and Robert Shaw at 22 Fore Street, Salcombe. Originally, it was heavily marketed towards university students, using the slogan and trademark "University Outfitters" to reflect the inspiration behind the brand. The "University Outfitters" slogan has slowly been replaced with the more favoured slogan "Fabulously British".
Founded by Dale Winfield in the early 1960s as a market stall selling slippers.
Founded as a manufacturer of women's stockings in Austria. The business operates 66 stand alone stores, 10 store in a store and concessions in the UK.
Founded by Courtesy Shoes after opening a new store in the former Wynsor House Discount Carpets store in Thurcroft. The brand replaced all Courtsey Shoes former brand Medina Shoes.
Founded in Chesterfield, Derbyshire by Walter Yeomans.
Created as You Must Create (YMC) in 1995 by Fraser Moss and Jimmy Collins. French Connection purchased the business during the late 1990s.
Founded by Andrew Killingsworth in the early 80s. Store sells Plus size lady clothing.
Founded by Amancio Ortega in A Coruña, Galicia, Spain. Opened first UK store in 1998.
Founded as a maker of fabrics in Italy after Ermenegildo Zegna bought his father's mill.
Founded in 1965, the business is known for its leather jackets
Founded by the Zenga family as a younger brand to the main Ermenegildo Zegna brand.
